data.body:
I guess it's a matter of turning this line:

https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/dev/src/textures/Texture.js#L104

Into this?

``` js
if ( meta !== undefined && meta.textures[ this.uuid ] !== undefined ) {
```

Hi, I've ran into the same problem using THREE.js r85. As stated in the [documentation regarding textures](https://threejs.org/docs/#api/textures/Texture), the `meta` parameter should be optional. However: If I simply pass nothing to the `.toJSON` Function, the application crashes. Code: ``` let testTex = new THREE.DataTexture(data, 1337, 1337); let json = testTex.toJSON(); ``` Error: > Cannot read property 'testTex.uuid' of undefined at DataTexture.toJSON (three.js:1072)
I briefly tried to work my way through the three.js lib in order to understand the origin of this meta parameter as three.js is apparently looking if the Textures UUID is availabe in this meta object. I don't know if this is correct, but it seems like three is trying to extract the textures informations from the meta object to do the conversion into a JSON object afterwards. A obvious problem occurs when this meta parameter is not filled, but I cant seem to figure out which parameter to pass into this function. Afaik, the toJSON Function is designed to be parameterless. If this is true, the meta object has to be available within the Texture class. **Possible quick fix:** After reading Issue [#8428](https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/issues/8428) I simply renamed the Textures' `toJSON` function and was able to stringify a texture of mine. Code: ``` let tex = new THREE.DataTexture(data, 1337, 1337); let temp = JSON.stringify(tex); ``` After brief observation of the temp variable, temp now contains the stringified version of my texture. **However:** After storing this string in a file using node's fileStream, the final file was 22MB in size, 3x bigger than my original resource (that is currently used to create Textures). Is this behaviour correct? I'm not sure if I got the "right thing" after the stringification. In addition, is it normal/predictable that the (possible) textures are this big once serialized? @mrdoob I would highly appreciate if you could take a look at the stuff I stated here. It seems (!) like the toJSON Function for Textures is currently bugged or should be renamed. I don't want to frame this as a bug, I just want to get a high quality answer from someone who understands three in a far better way than I do.
Regards, Michael

I have a similar problem, but not because `meta` was undefined. It's due to `toJSON` behaviour. By default, it is called by `JSON.stringify` with the property name as first arguments.

Example, if I call:
```js
JSON.stringify({ foo: 'bar', group: someThreeGroup });
```
when trying to serialize group, it will call Object3D.prototype.toJSON with `group` as first argument. so meta will be the string `group` which is not handled at all by the current code. I have edited the documentation on MDN to reflect the [ECMAScript6 specs about toJSON](https://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/6.0/#sec-serializejsonproperty).

I'll try to see if I can write a patch quickly.
